definition: to point out/to indicate

point/dot/drop/speck/o'clock/point (in space or time)/to draw a dot/to check on a list/to choose/to order (food in a restaurant)/to touch briefly/to hint/to light/to ignite/to pour a liquid drop by drop/(old) one fifth of a two-hour watch 更[geng1]/dot stroke in Chinese characters/classifier for items

to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc
variant of 出[chu1] (classifier for plays or chapters of classical novels)

sentences.english: The class should have begun at 1:15, but the professor was half an hour late.
sentences.chinese: 课本应该在1点出15分开始，但教授迟到了半小时。

sentences.english: You call me later how come out walk ?
At last, epilog point out real life meaning and negative-said influence.
sentences.chinese: 结语点出了崇陶的现实意义及负面影响。

definition: to point out
to lay bare in a few words/to expose with a word/to point out bluntly
vague/ambiguous/veiled/obscure
to hit the target (esp. in argument)/to strike home
to speak/to tell/to voice
vital part/(fig.) key point/crucial
to imply/to suggest/to connote/implicit
to expose/to reveal
to sketch in light shades/to play down/to deemphasize (idiom)
to hint at/to imply/sth hidden
to point towards/aimed at/facing/the direction indicated
to avoid the important and dwell on the trivial/to keep silent about major charges while admitting minor ones
thought-provoking/worth thinking over/to provide food for thought
concise and comprehensive (idiom)
to say straight out/to point out bluntly/to give a straightforward account/to disclose
to flash
